results.title: Tukiki and his search for a Merry Christmas
results.creator_credit: Vic Atkinson, Beryl Friesen, W.H. Stephens and Pooled Film Services
results.brief_description: An animated children’s film in which Tukiki, an Eskimo boy, sees Christmas celebrated all over the world. Uses beautiful xerox and pastel backgrounds throughout. Created and written by Christine Atkinson with the voice of Sterling Holloway.

results.title: True homance
results.brief_description: As a memorial to love, the filmmaker turns to the camera in an attempt to document the experiences he shared with his first boyfriend, only to find the filmmaking process as illusive as memory.

results.title: Trouble in town
results.creator_credit: Kevin Murray and Bairnsdale Technical School
results.brief_description: Under the supervision of Kevin Murray, 1st year Diploma students participated in a film exercise as part of their film appreciation classes. Their theme for practical study was the “classic chase” of the goodies after the baddies. This is a silent film.

results.title: Tropfest 2002 [DVD]
results.brief_description: From humble beginnings the Tropfest film festival first ran in 1993 at the Tropicana Caffe in Sydney’s Darlinghurst. The festival was founded by actor/director John Polson. In it’s tenth year Tropfest has swelled considerably. In 2002 the Intel Tropfest attracted an audience of over 100,000 in Australia (90,000 were at the Sydney screening alone!). The festival attracted a record amount of entries totalling 611 of which 16 finalists were screened. Each year a theme is set for entrants to the festival - this year’s theme was ‘Match’. This video contains the works of the 16 finalists of 2002 and includes the following titles: “Hommes du jour” (dir. Brian Moses); “The Arsonist’s riddle” (dir. Ben West); “Boomerring” (dir. Carla Drago); “Late night shopper” (dir. Tim Bullock); “The Flying nut” (dir. Dean White); “Lamb” (dir. Emma Freeman); “Wilfred” (dir. Tony Rogers); “Murbah swamp beer” (dir. Gary Doust); “The Thing in the roof” (dir. Walter Repich); “FA” (dir. Marie Craven); “Tragic love” (dir. Gary Eck); “Tiny little pieces” (dir. Trent O’Donnell and Phil Lloyd); “Clouds weep on the greenness” (dir. Suda Narayana); “Matchbox” (dir. Julius Avery); “How am I driving” (dir. Tim Dean); “I Can’t get started” (dir. Charles Williams). Website: www.tropfest.com

results.title: Tropfest #9 2001: 16 finalists
results.brief_description: The Sydney Film Festival, Tropfest, is the world’s largest short film festival, held one night in February each year at the Domain, Royal Botanic Gardens, Sydney. The aim is to showcase work from young and emerging filmmakers, providing them with a festival atmosphere to screen their works to peers. In an attempt to encourage production, not just the exhibition of films, the festival has a Tropfest Signature Item, announced a few months prior to the festival. Each film must contain the TSI in whatever form the filmmaker sees fit. In 2001, the TSI is ‘horn’ and the interpretations leap from, ‘The French’, to something a lot more personal. This tape contains 16 finalists which includes: “A Matter of life” (dir. Jennifer Perrott); “Tickler” (dir. Clayton Jacobson); “Muffled love” (dir. Rene Hernandez); “The Lighter” (dir. Patrick Hughes); “Just not cricket” (dir. Matt Wheeldon); “The Art of farewell” (dir. David Napier); “Beep” (dir. Eddie Edwards); “Like it is” (dirs. Chris Begley, Tony D’Aquino); “Home straight” (dir. Mickey Power); “Chopper” (dir. Bernard Derriman); “A Day at the zoo” (dir. Matthew Gidney); “Playin’ hard to get” (dir. Tim Bullock); “Boambee return” (dir. Liz Crosby); “Burn” (dir. Michael Dunning); “The Cutting room floor” (dir. Steve Baker); “Ride on” (dir. Nick Wyles).

results.title: Trik film three
results.creator_credit: George Griffin and Eccentric Circle Cinema Workshop
results.brief_description: A film experiment which uses one of the oldest methods of simple animation. The artist draws a series of pictures of a simple set of actions in progression. These are then stacked in the hand and flipped through to form a moving image. Useful for film making classes. Without commentary.

results.title: Trigger happy Harry
results.creator_credit: John B. Sandstone and Business Films
results.brief_description: Through the experiences of a careless and ignorant hunter, the safe and proper ways of handling a gun are taught. The National Rifle Association’s pointers for safety are covered: point the muzzle in a safe direction; is that gun loaded?; be sure of your target before you shoot; be sure of your backstop; know your gun and ammunition.

results.title: Struggle for oil
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”
Discusses the importance of oil in the world of today. Traces the growth of the oil industry from the beginning of the century, during the first and second world wars and in the post-war era. The Middle East as a source of oil is considered and the need for political stability in these areas emphasised. This stability can only be guaranteed if the rulers of these countries use profits from oil to improve the conditions of the people.

results.title: Lancashire's time for adventure
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
For more than 200 years cotton, grown on the other side of the world, has been coming to Britain to be spun and woven. A moist climate, money for the development of mills, and inventors whose machines taught mass-production to the world - Lancashire had all these. But today one-third of Lancashire’s spindles and looms are idle. The memory of past booms and slumps has resulted in a grave shortage of operators. Schemes to improve working conditions and wages have been put into operation.

results.title: The Rape of the earth
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
This film puts squarely before its audience the seriousness of the question of world-wide misuse of the soil resources of the earth. Primitive peoples have not caused more devastation than civilised peoples; in fact, they have caused less, for civilised humans organises agricultural and pastoral activities on a greater scale.
